stem: Based on the EHR, what actions should the nurse prioritize for this patient?

tabs.title: Nurses' Notes
tabs.content: 07:00: Patient (J.D.) started blood transfusion per order. 07:15: Patient reports feeling hot and anxious. 07:20: Noticed patient is flushed and has developed hives on their chest. Vital signs trending up. 07:25: Patient now reports back pain and increasing anxiety. Notified the charge nurse immediately. Possible transfusion reaction suspected. Continue to monitor vital signs closely. Oxygen applied via nasal cannula at 2L/min. Dr. Smith notified and awaiting orders. Patient is AAOx3. Continue to assess patient response to interventions and monitor for any further deterioration. 07:30: Urine output noted to be decreased and darker in color. Patient states 'I feel like something is really wrong.' 07:35: New order received from Dr. Smith to draw blood for DAT and send urine sample.

tabs.content: Current orders include: Blood transfusion (PRBCs) 1 unit, infuse over 2 hours. Monitor vital signs every 15 minutes during transfusion. Administer acetaminophen 650mg PO for fever >38.0째C. Oxygen via nasal cannula 2L PRN for SpO2 <92%.

rationale.correct: Hemolytic transfusion reactions are life-threatening and require immediate intervention. Stopping the transfusion is the first step to prevent further hemolysis and complications.
rationale.incorrect: Other options may be appropriate later, but addressing the immediate threat of a hemolytic reaction is paramount.

answerBreakdown.label: Blank 1
answerBreakdown.content: Hemolytic transfusion reactions involve the destruction of red blood cells by the recipient's immune system. Immediate cessation of the transfusion minimizes further exposure to the incompatible blood and reduces the severity of the reaction.

answerBreakdown.label: Blank 2
answerBreakdown.content: The patient's symptoms (fever, chills, back pain, dark urine, positive DAT, decreased Hgb/Hct) strongly suggest a hemolytic transfusion reaction. These symptoms arise from the rapid destruction of red blood cells and the release of intracellular components into the circulation.

clinicalPearls: Hemolytic transfusion reactions can be acute or delayed. Acute reactions occur within 24 hours of the transfusion, while delayed reactions occur days to weeks later.
Always verify blood product compatibility before initiating a transfusion.
Monitor patients closely for signs and symptoms of transfusion reactions during and after the transfusion.

A positive DAT (Direct Antiglobulin Test) indicates that antibodies or complement proteins are attached to the surface of red blood cells, which supports the diagnosis of a hemolytic transfusion reaction.

questionTrap.trap: Selecting 'administer acetaminophen' might seem appropriate because the patient has a fever. However, the fever is a symptom of a more serious problem (hemolytic reaction) that needs immediate attention.
questionTrap.howToOvercome: Prioritize actions based on the underlying cause of the patient's symptoms. In this case, the hemolytic reaction is the priority.

mnemonic.title: STOP the Reaction
mnemonic.expansion: S - Stop the transfusion. T - Take vital signs. O - Obtain urine and blood samples. P - Provide supportive care (oxygen, fluids).
